failure_modes.description: Believing you have a moat when you don't
failure_modes.real_world_case: Groupon - thought they had network effects, actually had no moat. Competitors copied easily.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True moat = ability to raise prices 10% without losing customers

failure_modes.real_world_case: IBM mainframe moat - eroded over decades as computing shifted to PCs and cloud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Margin decline > 2% annually indicates moat erosion

failure_modes.real_world_case: Nokia's brand moat - strong brand wasn't enough when smartphone disruption hit.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Best businesses have 3+ moat sources

failure_modes.real_world_case: Luxury brands licensing - short-term revenue but dilutes brand moat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Growth that reduces ROIC by > 5% is moat-destructive

failure_modes.description: Moats dependent on regulation can disappear
failure_modes.real_world_case: Taxi medallion collapse - Uber showed regulatory moats can be disrupted.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory moats have 20-year half-life on average

failure_modes.real_world_case: Sears - strong brand couldn't save declining product and service quality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Brand premium sustainable only with top-quartile quality

failure_modes.real_world_case: Harley-Davidson perfume - brand extension that damaged core brand equity.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Extensions > 2 categories from core risk brand dilution

failure_modes.description: Brand doesn't resonate with new generations
failure_modes.real_world_case: Golf brands - strong with boomers, struggling to attract millennials.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Brands need 20%+ customers under 35 for longevity

failure_modes.description: Brand reputation destroyed by viral incidents
failure_modes.real_world_case: United Airlines passenger dragging - viral video caused massive brand damage.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Viral negative events can reduce brand value 10-30% overnight

failure_modes.description: Brand in commoditizing category loses relevance
failure_modes.real_world_case: PC brands - as PCs commoditized, brand premiums collapsed.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Brand premium < 10% indicates commodity trap

failure_modes.description: Assuming customers are more locked in than they are
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blackberry enterprise - thought switching costs were high, iPhone made switching worthwhile.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs must exceed 20% of annual value to be effective

failure_modes.description: Customers resent lock-in and leave when possible
failure_modes.real_world_case: Cable TV bundles - forced bundling created resentment, customers fled to streaming.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: NPS < 0 with high switching costs indicates resentment

failure_modes.real_world_case: Bank account switching - fintech APIs made switching much easier.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: APIs can reduce switching costs by 50-80%

failure_modes.real_world_case: Number portability - telecom switching costs reduced by regulation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Portability mandates reduce switching costs 30-60%

failure_modes.real_world_case: Enterprise software - high switching costs masked declining value, eventual mass exodus.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Usage declining while retention stable = switching cost dependence

failure_modes.real_world_case: Craigslist - network effects leaked to specialized verticals (Indeed, Zillow, etc.).
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Vertical specialists can capture 30-50% of category value

failure_modes.real_world_case: Facebook news feed - growth brought spam, misinformation, reduced quality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Quality metrics must improve with scale, not just quantity

failure_modes.real_world_case: Ride-sharing - despite network effects, Uber and Lyft coexist.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Multi-homing > 20% prevents winner-take-all

failure_modes.description: Network effects take time to build
failure_modes.real_world_case: Many social apps - ran out of money before reaching network effect scale.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Network effects typically require 3-5 years to become defensible

failure_modes.real_world_case: Twitter toxicity - more users brought more harassment, drove away others.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Negative externalities can offset positive at scale > 100M users

failure_modes.real_world_case: Southwest Airlines - cost advantages copied by other low-cost carriers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cost advantages erode 5-10% annually without reinvestment

failure_modes.description: Getting too big creates cost disadvantages
failure_modes.real_world_case: Walmart in small towns - scale advantages don't apply, local competitors win.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Diseconomies typically emerge above 30% market share

failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak's film cost advantage - digital eliminated film entirely.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Technology disruption can eliminate 100% of cost advantage

failure_modes.real_world_case: China manufacturing - labor cost advantage eroding as wages rise.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Labor cost advantages halve every 10-15 years in developing markets

failure_modes.real_world_case: Boeing 737 MAX - cost pressure contributed to safety compromises.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Quality issues can destroy 10x the cost savings

failure_modes.real_world_case: Pharmaceutical patent cliffs - blockbuster drugs lose 80%+ revenue at expiration.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Plan for 80% revenue loss at patent expiration

failure_modes.real_world_case: Smartphone patent wars - companies found workarounds for most patents.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 50%+ of patents can be designed around within 5 years

failure_modes.description: Secrets leak through employees or espionage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Waymo vs Uber - trade secrets allegedly stolen by departing employee.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Trade secrets leak within 5-7 years on average

failure_modes.description: Patents don't matter without ability to execute
failure_modes.real_world_case: Xerox PARC - invented GUI, mouse, ethernet but failed to commercialize.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 90% of patents generate zero commercial value

failure_modes.description: Open source alternatives eliminate IP value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Linux vs Unix - open source eliminated proprietary Unix value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Open source can commoditize IP within 10 years

failure_modes.real_world_case: Airline deregulation - regulatory moats eliminated overnight.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory moats face major challenge every 15-20 years

failure_modes.real_world_case: Fintech vs banks - lighter regulation enabled fintech competition.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory arbitrage can provide 20-30% cost advantage

failure_modes.real_world_case: Corporate inversions - companies moved to lower-regulation jurisdictions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory differences > 10% of costs drive relocation

failure_modes.real_world_case: Sarbanes-Oxley - compliance costs drove companies private or overseas.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compliance > 5% of revenue indicates regulatory burden

failure_modes.description: Relying on regulation instead of competing
failure_modes.real_world_case: Taxi industry - relied on medallion system, didn't innovate, lost to Uber.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory-dependent businesses underperform by 3-5% annually

failure_modes.real_world_case: DTC brands vs retail - Warby Parker, Dollar Shave Club bypassed traditional distribution.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: DTC can capture 30-50% of category within 10 years

failure_modes.real_world_case: Zynga on Facebook - platform changes devastated business.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: No single platform > 30% of distribution for safety

failure_modes.description: Distribution costs rise faster than value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Google/Facebook ad costs - customer acquisition costs rose faster than LTV.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: CAC/LTV > 0.33 indicates distribution cost problem

failure_modes.real_world_case: Apple losing AT&T exclusivity - distribution moat eliminated when iPhone went multi-carrier.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Exclusivity typically lasts 2-5 years before competitive pressure

failure_modes.real_world_case: Amazon logistics - built own last mile, reducing UPS/FedEx moat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Last mile is 50%+ of delivery cost, key battleground

failure_modes.real_world_case: Weather data - once proprietary, now commoditized through government and sensors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Data advantages halve every 3-5 years without renewal

failure_modes.description: Privacy laws limit data collection and use
failure_modes.real_world_case: GDPR impact - limited data collection and required consent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: GDPR reduced available data by 30-50% for many companies

failure_modes.real_world_case: Open banking - banks required to share customer data with competitors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Data portability can eliminate 50%+ of data moat value

failure_modes.real_world_case: Contact databases - data decays 30% annually as people change jobs.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: B2B data decays 30% annually, consumer data 20%

failure_modes.description: AI-generated data reduces real data advantage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Autonomous vehicle training - synthetic data reducing need for real-world miles.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Synthetic data can replace 50-80% of training data needs

failure_modes.real_world_case: Uber culture problems - rapid growth brought culture that enabled misconduct.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Growing > 50% annually risks culture dilution

failure_modes.real_world_case: Apple post-Jobs (1985) - culture deteriorated without founder.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Culture typically degrades 20-30% within 5 years of founder departure

failure_modes.real_world_case: Microsoft under Ballmer - competitive culture hindered collaboration needed for cloud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Culture-strategy misalignment reduces execution by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Culture used to justify bad behavior
failure_modes.real_world_case: Theranos 'secrecy culture' - used to hide fraud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Culture that enables misconduct will eventually cause catastrophic failure

failure_modes.real_world_case: Google's perks copied widely - free food, etc. became industry standard.
safeguards: Build deep culture not just perks
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Surface culture elements copied within 2-3 years
